answers: degree(s) of freedom [or modes; prompt on Euler angles]
6 [accept 6n] (for a system of n rigid bodies, they will have 6n degrees of freedom)
kinematic coupling [prompt on Principle of Exact Constraint Design; anti-prompt “be less specific” on Kelvin Coupling or Maxwell Coupling]
parts: Name these parameters measuring the parts of a system that can vary independently. Airplane physics often involve the pitch, yaw, and roll, which correspond to the rotational type of these values.
According to the mobility formula, this is the number of degrees of freedom that one rigid body will possess when moving relative to a fixed frame.

This concept from precision design describes the engineering of support devices to exactly constrain the six available degrees of freedom for a part of interest. This approach uses exactly one contact point to constrain each degree of freedom.

answers: Kent State Massacre [accept synonyms of massacre, like shooting, killing, etc.]
parts: Name this 1970 massacre in which the National Guard killed four students at an Ohio University.
Ten days after the Kent State massacre, police killed two people at a university in this state. This state’s black activists organized a “Freedom Summer” to register black voters.
This initiative began in Marks, Mississippi and featured a camp at Resurrection City that elected Jesse Jackson mayor.

answers: Hanging Poems [or Muʻallaqāt; or Suspended Odes]
parts: Name this group of 7 works of poetry, which are named for their position within the Ka’aba. These works were held to have been written by the Seven Renowned Ones.

The Hanging Poems are among the most prominent examples of pre-Islamic literature in this language. The verses of the Qur'an are often held to be the most important pieces of poetic literature in this language.
This Palestinian author, the most famous contemporary poet to use Arabic, proclaimed “Write down! I am an Arab” in his poem “Identity Card.”
Name this design theorist, who used the phrase "user centered design" in his most famous book, The Design of Everyday Things.

In The Design of Everyday Things, Norman demonstrated his concept of the "user centered design" with the example of how handlebars, reins, and joysticks have been used to control these devices. Norman also described the design of these devices in the book Turn Signals are the Smiles of these devices.
In a chapter titled "The Psychopathology of Everyday Things," Norman argued that handles or plates on these household objects can be designed to "afford" pushing or pulling in their use.

answers: DeMarcus “Boogie” Cousins [accept DeMarcus Amir Cousins; prompt on just “Boogie”]
Stephen “Steph” Curry [or Wardell Stephen Curry II]
parts: Name this player who signed with the Golden State Warriors in the 2018 offseason only to get injured and lose to the Toronto Raptors in the finals. He gained the nickname “Boogie” while on the Sacramento Kings.

Cousins and Jackson spoke on the All the Smoke podcast on SHOWTIME hosted by Jackson and this former NBA tough-guy. This former player beat up Derek Fisher after he was found out to be dating this player’s ex-wife, Gloria Govan.
Barnes and Cousins both ended up ring-chasing on the Warriors, led by this sharpshooting 2-time MVP.

answers: Jelly’s Last Jam (The musical is about Jelly Roll Morton)
parts: Cole Porter provided the score for this Bella and Samuel Spewack musical about a theatrical production of Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew. It was the recipient of the inaugural Tony Award for Best Musical.

The story of the title band leader’s upbringing in a Creole family from New Orleans and experiences learning from Blues musician Buddy Bolden is told in this 1992 musical. This musical concludes with the title character proclaiming “I was wrong, I was wrong!” before embracing the profound role his upbringing had on his music.

The music of this jazz pianist was the basis for the 1981 musical Sophisticated Ladies, which includes such hits by him as “Take the A Train”, “Mood Indigo”, and “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got that Swing)”.

answers: Synod of Dort [or Synod of Dordt or Synod of Dordrecht]
parts: Name this 1618 to 1619 synod in the Netherlands convened to settle the Arminian controversy. This meeting saw disputes between the Arminians and followers of Franciscus Gomarus, as well as the condemnation of Johan von Oldenbarnevelt.
The Synod of Dort center on discussions of this theologian, whose ideology centered on the idea of predestination and ruled over Geneva.

This orthodox Calvinist founded the Anti-Revolutionary Party while Dutch Prime Minister. This politician promoted “pillarization”, or the division of Dutch society into pillars, based on the Netherlands’ many religions.

answers: Edgar Allan Poe (the poem is “The Tomb of Edgar Poe” by Stephane Mallarmé)
parts: Name this French literary movement, preceded by Parnassianism, that favored visions and dreams over realism. Writers in this movement included the lovers Arthur Rimbaud and Paul Verlaine.
This Symbolist poet addressed the “hypocrite reader” in a poem from his collection Les Fleurs du Mal.

This American author was a major inspiration to the Symbolist movement, especially Baudelaire, who translated some of his stories into French. A Symbolist poem about this author’s “dazzling sepulchre” ends by describing “the black flights of Blasphemy scattered into the future.”

answers: azide and alkyne [accept in either order; accept Azide-Alkyne cycloaddition]
parts: Name these two functional groups that are the classical inputs to the Huisgen cycloaddition. One consists of 2 carbon atoms separated by a triple bond, and the other consists of 3 linear nitrogen atoms separated by double bonds. Name both.

Reacting an azide and an alkyne in the Huisgen cycloaddition yields one of these compounds. Reacting hydrazine with an imide produces substituted examples of these compounds in the Einhorn-Brunner reaction.

Triazole-based guanidinium salt catalysts have become the preferred catalysts for this general type of reaction, which forms new bonds between amino acids and makes use of F-moc and Boc protecting groups in its “solid phase” variant.

answers: Spanish Civil War [or Guerra Civil Española]
parts: Name this teacher at the Marcia Blaine School for Girls who mentors six students she calls the “crème de la crème.”

Miss Brodie encourages her student Joyce Emily to fight in this conflict, leading to Joyce Emily’s death. Another British author described being shot in the throat by a sniper in an account of this conflict.
This author fought for the Republican army during the Spanish Civil War, which was recounted in Homage to Catalonia. He allegorized Hitler and Stalin as pigs in the novella Animal Farm.

answers: Robert Menzies [or Sir Robert Gordon Menzies]
parts: Name this country. Harold Holt, a prime minister of this country, disappeared while swimming off the coast at Cheviot Beach.
During Holt’s premiership, a referendum was held on the legal rights of these native inhabitants of Australia.

This longest-serving prime minister of Australia delivered the “Forgotten People” speech about the country’s working class. This politician failed in negotiations with Gamel Abdel Nasser during the Suez Crisis.
Name this process of translating source code into machine code. Programs that perform this process create bytecode to work in tandem with virtual machines.
When compilers are self-hosting, or written in the same language that they intend to compile, they are described by this term. This term is a reference to the compiler’s self-starting ability.
Since 2010, this language developed by Mozilla’s Graydon Hoare has made use of a self-hosting compiler. Since 2016, this language has been voted the “most loved” language by StackOverflow developers.

answers: al-Ghazali [Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad al-Ghazālī; accept Algazelus]
parts: Name this rationalist school of Islamic theology whose name references the fact that its founder, Wasil ibn Ata, “withdrew from” the theological circle of Hasan of Basra. Qadi Abd al-Jabbar is a prominent scholar from this sect.

Historically, intolerant Mu’tazali policies have been linked to the birth of the Ash’ari sect, whose most well-known adherent is probably this medieval philosopher. This scholar attacked the Aristotelian theories of falsafa philosophy in his The Incoherence of the Philosophers.
The Mu’tazila school grew to prominence in this city in modern-day Iraq, where practitioners of Islamic theology met to teach at its House of Wisdom.
Name this Oskar Schlemmer ballet with music by Paul Hindemuth. Designed to evoke the mechanical motion of marionettes, it remains one of the most widely performed avant-garde ballets of all time.

A similar mechanical style of motion is adopted by the title life-sized doll, whose realistic beauty distracts Franz from his romance with Swanhilde, in this Leo Delibes ballet. It features a notable “Waltz of the Hours”.

Probably the most prominent example of puppetry in ballet can be seen in Petrushka, a work by this Russian composer of The Rite of Spring, which tells the story of a magician cursed to bring a puppet to life.

answers: Kabbalah [prompt on Jewish mysticism; prompt on Judaism]
Shimon bar Yochai (yo-hai) [or Simeon ben Yohai; accept Rashbi but do NOT accept or prompt on "Rashi"]
parts: Name this mystical religious tradition, which believes that God created the world through a process of "contraction," or tzimtzum. This tradition also venerates the 10 emanations, known as the Sefirot.

According to Kabbalahist tradition, this Roman era Rabbi was the author of the Zohar, the major text of Kabbalah. According to tradition, while this rabbi hid in a cave, the angel Metatron revealed the future Islamic rule of Israel.

Metatron's prophecy to Shimon bar Yochai ends with the arrival of this figure, who then kills the final Islamic ruler. This figure is believed to be a future Jewish king, while in Christianity this figure is believed to be Jesus.
Name this town in New Mexico, which contained an artist’s colony founded by Mabel Dodge Luhan. Artists such as Ansel Adams worked in this town beginning in the 1920s.

This artist produced many paintings of desert landscapes, such as Ram’s Head White Hollyhock, while working in Taos. This artist’s former studio in Taos, the Abiquiu home, contains a famous black door and is now a museum.
O’Keeffe may be better known for her paintings of these natural objects, which are depicted in her Red Canna series, and are often interpreted to have a suggestive nature.

answers: ecological systems theory [or human ecology theory; accept bioecological theory; accept but do not otherwise reveal development in context theory; accept "model" in place of "theory" for any answer]
parts: Name this theory developed by Urie Bronfenbrenner. Later versions of this theoretical model add biological factors such as age and sex.

In the book Making Human Beings, Bronfenbrenner describes his bioecological perspective on this process. Fellow Soviet born thinker Lev Vygotsky created the pivot model of this process and describes a zone of the proximal form of this process.
A later revision to the ecological systems model added the chronosystem, which analyzes this variable and physical context. Longitudinal studies track data over the course of this variable.

answers: hybrid sterility [accept word forms for sterility]
allopatric speciation [prompt on speciation; accept vicariance model of allopatric speciation]
parts: Name this Ukranian-American evolutionary biologist and author of the pioneering textbook Genetics and the Origin of Species. With Muller and Bateson, he co-names a model of genetic incompatibility.

Dobzhansky-Muller incompatibilities are one contributing factor to this general phenomenon in which the F1 generation from two different species are unable to overcome prezygotic barriers and cannot reproduce.

One way in which fertile, new species are actually created is when a geographic barrier bisects a population. That is the vicariance-driven version of this biological process, which is contrasted with its sympatric counterpart.

answers: Simon Bolivar [or Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios Ponte-Andrade y Blanco]
parts: Name this general, who adopted the dog Nevado during the Admirable Campaign, which helped earn him the nickname “the Liberator”.

These herders called Bolivar “iron buttocks” for his ability to endure long travel on horseback. These people fought at the Battle of Las Queseras del Medio, where they were told to “return to the battle, damn it!” by Jose Antonio Páez.
This other Bolivarian supporter famously challenged his troops to “live with honor or die with glory” at the Battle of El Roble. This Irish general lost at the Disaster of Rancagua.

answers: Mr. Flood [or Eben Flood; accept “Mr. Flood’s Party”]
parts: Name this character whose “party” titles a poem set in Tilbury Town.
This author of “Mr. Flood’s Party” used Tilbury Town as a setting for many of his poems, including “Miniver Cheevy” and “Richard Cory.”

This poem by Robinson claims “The darkness is a sullen thing” before stating the title characters “seem lost in fortune’s winnowing.” It is the title poem of a collection that contains “Luke Havergal” and “Richard Cory.”
